definitions: discuss and arrange the terms of an agreement or contract again to reach better conditions
examples: The workers decided to renegotiate their contract for higher wages
We need to renegotiate the loan terms with the bank

definitions: restore something to its original condition or replace it with something new
extend the period of validity of a license agreement or subscription
examples: Spring is the perfect time to renew your garden with fresh plants
The couple decided to renew their wedding vows after twenty years
Don't forget to renew your driver's license before it expires next month
The library automatically renews books if no one else requests them

definitions: formally declare that you no longer have or want something especially a belief claim or position
examples: The prince decided to renounce his claim to the throne
She had to renounce her citizenship when she moved abroad

definitions: repair and improve a building or room by fixing damage and adding new features
examples: They plan to renovate the old farmhouse over the summer months
The school renovated its science labs with modern equipment

definitions: open a place or business again after it has been closed for some time
examples: The restaurant will reopen next week after the kitchen repairs
They decided to reopen the case when new evidence appeared

definitions: change the way something is arranged structured or managed to work more effectively
examples: We need to reorganise the office to create more meeting spaces
The company will reorganise its departments to improve communication

definitions: change the way something is arranged structured or managed to work more effectively
examples: We need to reorganize the office to create more meeting spaces
The company will reorganize its departments to improve communication

definitions: apply a new coat of paint to something that has already been painted
examples: We should repaint the fence before winter arrives this year
The artist decided to repaint the portrait with brighter colors

definitions: send someone back to their own country especially refugees prisoners or people working abroad
examples: The embassy helped repatriate citizens after the natural disaster struck
Many companies repatriate their profits from overseas operations

definitions: give back money that you have borrowed from someone or an institution
do something good for someone who has helped you or been kind
examples: She promised to repay the loan within three years time
He worked extra hours to repay his credit card debt
How can I ever repay you for all your help and support
She repaid his kindness by helping him find a new job

definitions: officially cancel or withdraw a law rule or act of legislation
examples: Congress voted to repeal the controversial tax law last year
The government promised to repeal outdated regulations affecting small businesses

definitions: drive or force something away by pushing against it or using opposing force
cause someone to feel intense distaste or disgust for something
examples: The spray helps repel mosquitoes during outdoor summer activities
The castle walls were built to repel enemy attacks
The smell of rotten eggs repels most people from the area
His rude behavior repels potential friends at social gatherings

definitions: feel sincere regret or remorse about wrongdoing and resolve to change
examples: He began to repent his harsh words to his brother
The criminal claimed to repent for all his past crimes

definitions: play a recording game or match again from the beginning
experience or remember an event as if it is happening again
examples: Let's replay the video to see what really happened there
The team will replay the championship match next Saturday
She kept replaying the conversation in her mind all night
History tends to replay itself when we forget important lessons

definitions: fill something up again by replacing what has been used or lost
examples: Remember to replenish the water bottles before the long hike
The store needs to replenish its inventory after the holiday sale

definitions: filled or well-supplied with something especially to the point of excess
examples: The report was replete with errors and misleading information
The garden is replete with colorful flowers in spring

definitions: make an exact copy of something or reproduce results under the same conditions
examples: Scientists tried to replicate the experiment in different laboratories worldwide
The artist can replicate famous paintings with amazing accuracy

definitions: lie or be at rest in a peaceful calm or relaxed state
examples: The cat likes to repose in sunny spots around the house
His body will repose in the family cemetery

definitions: move something to a different place or change its position for better effect
examples: We need to reposition the furniture to create more space
The company wants to reposition itself as a luxury brand

definitions: forcefully prevent feelings thoughts or desires from being expressed or remembered
examples: He tried to repress his anger during the tense meeting
Some people repress painful memories from their childhood years

definitions: cancel or postpone punishment especially a death sentence giving temporary relief
examples: The governor granted a reprieve to the condemned prisoner
The rain gave us a reprieve from the scorching heat

definitions: formally express sharp disapproval or criticism of someone for their behavior
examples: The teacher had to reprimand the student for cheating on the test
His boss will reprimand him for arriving late to work again

definitions: print more copies of a book article or document that has already been published
examples: The publisher decided to reprint the bestselling novel for Christmas
They had to reprint the brochures after finding several spelling errors

definitions: repeat a piece of music or a performance especially near the end
examples: The singer will reprise her hit song at the concert finale
The actor agreed to reprise his famous role in the sequel

definitions: express disappointment or displeasure with someone for something they have done
examples: She could not help but reproach him for breaking his promise
His mother would reproach him for not calling more often

definitions: make a copy of something such as a document picture or sound
produce offspring through biological processes in plants animals or humans
examples: The printer can reproduce high-quality images from digital files
It's illegal to reproduce copyrighted material without permission
Rabbits reproduce quickly and can have many babies each year
Some plants reproduce by spreading seeds through the wind

definitions: refuse to accept or be associated with something by rejecting it publicly
examples: The senator decided to repudiate his earlier statements about the policy
She had to repudiate the false accusations made against her

definitions: drive back an attacking enemy force by fighting against them
cause someone to feel intense disgust or strong aversion
examples: The defenders managed to repulse the enemy attack at dawn
The small army repulsed three waves of invaders
The graphic images of violence repulse many television viewers
His arrogant attitude tends to repulse potential business partners

definitions: buy something back that you previously owned or sold to someone else
examples: The company plans to repurchase shares to increase stock value
He decided to repurchase his childhood home from the new owners

definitions: believe or consider someone or something to have a particular quality
examples: The restaurant is reputed to serve the best seafood in town
She is reputed to be one of the finest surgeons

definitions: officially demand or take something especially for military or public use
examples: The army had to requisition vehicles from local residents
The hospital will requisition extra supplies for the emergency

definitions: run a race or competition again usually due to problems with the first attempt
broadcast a television program or movie that has been shown before
examples: They had to rerun the race after a false start
The computer will rerun the program to check for errors
The channel will rerun classic sitcoms during the summer months
They always rerun holiday movies in December

definitions: arrange for an event or appointment to take place at a different time
examples: We need to reschedule the meeting due to the storm warning
The airline had to reschedule flights because of mechanical problems

definitions: revoke cancel or repeal a law order or decision with official authority
examples: The company decided to rescind its job offer after the background check
The court may rescind the contract if fraud is proven

definitions: sell something that you have bought to another person or business
examples: He plans to resell vintage clothing at a higher price
The company will resell returned items at a discount

definitions: feel bitterness or anger about something you think is unfair or wrong
examples: She began to resent her sister's constant success and attention
Many employees resent having to work overtime without extra pay

definitions: set adjust or fix something again to its original or different position
examples: You need to reset your password for better account security
The technician will reset the router to fix the connection

definitions: move to live permanently in a different place or help others do so
examples: The refugees will resettle in several different countries this year
After the flood many families had to resettle in safer areas

definitions: give something a new or different shape form or structure
examples: Exercise and diet can help reshape your body over time
The new CEO wants to reshape the company's business strategy

definitions: reorganize something by changing the positions of people or things within it
examples: The prime minister decided to reshuffle the cabinet positions
We need to reshuffle the teams for better project outcomes

definitions: live in a particular place as your permanent home or for an extended period
examples: The ambassador will reside in the capital city for four years
Many retired people choose to reside in warmer climates

definitions: produce a deep clear sound that continues to vibrate or echo
evoke emotions or create a strong connection with someone's feelings or beliefs
examples: The bell continues to resonate long after being struck
His deep voice resonates throughout the concert hall
Her speech about equality resonates with young voters across the country
The movie's message about family resonates with audiences worldwide

definitions: start something again after it has stopped working or been interrupted
examples: Please restart your computer to apply the software updates
We had to restart the game after the power went out

definitions: prevent someone or something from doing something by holding them back physically or through control
examples: The security guards had to restrain the angry customer
She struggled to restrain her tears during the emotional speech

definitions: organize a system company or organization differently to make it more effective
examples: The bank plans to restructure its loans to help struggling homeowners
They need to restructure the department to reduce operating costs

definitions: put a new surface on something like a road or sports court
appear again after being hidden absent or forgotten for some time
examples: The city will resurface Main Street during the summer months
Workers need to resurface the tennis courts before the tournament
Old rumors tend to resurface during election campaigns
The missing painting resurfaced at an auction house years later

definitions: bring something back into use or existence after it has ended or been forgotten
examples: The studio wants to resurrect the popular TV series from the eighties
They plan to resurrect old traditions for the town festival

definitions: bring someone back to consciousness or life using medical procedures like CPR
examples: The paramedics worked to resuscitate the drowning victim
Doctors managed to resuscitate the patient after cardiac arrest

definitions: take a test exam or photograph again to get a better result
examples: Students can retake the exam if they fail the first time
The photographer asked them to retake the family portrait

definitions: make an attack in return for a similar attack or harm someone because they harmed you
examples: The country threatened to retaliate if attacked by its neighbors
She wanted to retaliate against those who spread false rumors
